transcription: Welcome everyone to this month's project status assembly. Today I am going to walk you through the full story of where we are with the Rumble AI project, what we are trying to achieve, what we have completed so far, the challenges we have identified, what we are actively working on, and what we plan to do next. Let's begin with the vision behind the project. To start with, our objective is to build an end-to-end AI solution for Rumble videos. In the first phase, we are focusing on two key capabilities. The first is to automatically generate short engaging moments for long-term videos to help increase user engagement. The second is to create a video aware search experience, one that goes beyond video titles and metadata and actually understands the content inside a video. With this vision in place, we have already made a strong progress. Over the past few weeks, we have built multiple prototypes that function as a separate service within our large moment generation system. We started by conducting extensive research and transcription generation, identified what works best for our use case, and even shared the results with Rumble to help unblo their transcription pipeline updates. In parallel, we developed prototypes for audio captioning, video captioning and emotion analysis using audio captions. And we also explored relevant research papers already addressing the similar challenges. Additionally, we evaluated several external vendors to understand whether they could accelerate the development. After analyzing their strategies alongside our findings, we concluded that an iterative in-house approach supported by a slightly large internal team is the best path forward. Now, through all this work, we have gained clarity on the key challenges we must solve to reach high quality results. Two of the biggest challenges are temporal alignment and long token context requirements. We also learned that popular semantic similarity-based approach for long context tasks actually performs worse than a regular LLM in our use case. On the positive side, we now know the best models for transcription generation and we understand that to surpass the high-end commercial models, we need to iteratively fine-tune our own models. Models that are more cost effective and trained specifically for this exact task. Moving forward confidently will also require a well-defined data set along with a testing and evaluation strategy so that we can track improvements reliably. With this understanding, let me share what we are focusing on right now. We are currently building a two-phased moments generation pipeline inspired by research observations that most meaningful moments are driven by the words in the video and raw video frames add only minimal value in many cases. Based on that insight, we are working on a two-phase approach where our first phase generates course timestamps using only time scripts. And in the second phase, we refine those timestamps using a final transcript along with selected video frames to produce polished high-quality moment. The important part here is that this is no longer just theoretical. We now have a working demo generating two-phased moments using transcripts alone. In the coming weeks, we will integrate video frames into the same pipeline to enhance accuracy even further and work on this integration is already underway. Looking ahead, our priorities are very clear. First, we need to build a robust evaluation data set and a strong measurement strategy to evaluate our incremental progress. Second, we will continue exploring more efficient approaches for moment generation that reduces cost, time, and infrastructure requirement. And third, to accelerate all of this, we plan to hire two additional team members, one with expertise in AI model research and another full stack developer who can work effectively with AI models. That brings us to the end of this update. If you have any questions about anything we have discussed, I'll be happy to answer them.

segment_timestamps.text: Welcome everyone to this month's project status assembly.

Today I am going to walk you through the full story of where we are with the Rumble AI project, what we are trying to achieve, what we have completed so far, the challenges we have identified, what we are actively working on, and what we plan to do next.
Let's begin with the vision behind the project.
To start with, our objective is to build an end-to-end AI solution for Rumble videos.
In the first phase, we are focusing on two key capabilities.
The first is to automatically generate short engaging moments for long-term videos to help increase user engagement.
The second is to create a video aware search experience, one that goes beyond video titles and metadata and actually understands the content inside a video.
With this vision in place, we have already made a strong progress.
Over the past few weeks, we have built multiple prototypes that function as a separate service within our large moment generation system.

We started by conducting extensive research and transcription generation, identified what works best for our use case, and even shared the results with Rumble to help unblo their transcription pipeline updates.
In parallel, we developed prototypes for audio captioning, video captioning and emotion analysis using audio captions.
And we also explored relevant research papers already addressing the similar challenges.
Additionally, we evaluated several external vendors to understand whether they could accelerate the development.
After analyzing their strategies alongside our findings, we concluded that an iterative in-house approach supported by a slightly large internal team is the best path forward.
Now, through all this work, we have gained clarity on the key challenges we must solve to reach high quality results.
Two of the biggest challenges are temporal alignment and long token context requirements.
We also learned that popular semantic similarity-based approach for long context tasks actually performs worse than a regular LLM in our use case.
On the positive side, we now know the best models for transcription generation and we understand that to surpass the high-end commercial models, we need to iteratively fine-tune our own models.
Models that are more cost effective and trained specifically for this exact task.
Moving forward confidently will also require a well-defined data set along with a testing and evaluation strategy so that we can track improvements reliably.
With this understanding, let me share what we are focusing on right now.

We are currently building a two-phased moments generation pipeline inspired by research observations that most meaningful moments are driven by the words in the video and raw video frames add only minimal value in many cases.
Based on that insight, we are working on a two-phase approach where our first phase generates course timestamps using only time scripts.
And in the second phase, we refine those timestamps using a final transcript along with selected video frames to produce polished high-quality moment.
The important part here is that this is no longer just theoretical.
We now have a working demo generating two-phased moments using transcripts alone.
In the coming weeks, we will integrate video frames into the same pipeline to enhance accuracy even further and work on this integration is already underway.
Looking ahead, our priorities are very clear.
First, we need to build a robust evaluation data set and a strong measurement strategy to evaluate our incremental progress.
Second, we will continue exploring more efficient approaches for moment generation that reduces cost, time, and infrastructure requirement.
And third, to accelerate all of this, we plan to hire two additional team members, one with expertise in AI model research and another full stack developer who can work effectively with AI models.
That brings us to the end of this update.
If you have any questions about anything we have discussed, I'll be happy to answer them.
